articles.headline: Dow Closes Above 17,000 as Stock Rally Outpaces Economy
articles.snippet: The current bull market has lasted nearly 64 months, making it the fourth-longest since the crash of 1929, and investors are showing few signs of slowing down.
articles.abstract: The current bull market has lasted nearly 64 months, making it the fourth-longest since the crash of 1929, and investors are showing few signs of slowing down.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market, continuing a remarkable ascent that began in the darkness of the last recession, surged past a milestone on Thursday after a strong jobs report indicated that the economy might finally be gaining steam.

articles.headline: Today’s Titans Can Learn From Fall of U.S. Steel
articles.snippet: A once-powerful corporation has been dropped from the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, but the fact that it’s down may not mean that it’s out.
articles.abstract: A once-powerful corporation has been dropped from the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, but the fact that it’s down may not mean that it’s out.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been 55 years since bitter labor relations exploded into one of the longest and most debilitating strikes the United States has ever seen.

articles.headline: Services Emerge to Help Out-of-State Students Pay In-State Tuition
articles.snippet: Companies like In-State Angels are trying to help students and parents avoid the high price of out-of-state tuition, but some colleges frown on it.
articles.abstract: Companies like In-State Angels are trying to help students and parents avoid the high price of out-of-state tuition, but some colleges frown on it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Figuring out how to pay in-state college tuition for a college student who grew up elsewhere is the ultimate money hack.

articles.headline: Birth Control Order Deepens Divide Among Justices
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court temporarily barred the government from enforcing against a Christian college a contraception rule under the Affordable Care Act, drawing a furious dissent from the three female justices, who said the court had broken a promise.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court temporarily barred the government from enforcing against a Christian college a contraception rule under the Affordable Care Act, drawing a furious dissent from the three female justices, who said the court had broken a promise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a decision that drew an unusually fierce dissent from the three female justices, the Supreme Court sided Thursday with religiously affiliated nonprofit groups in a clash between religious freedom and women’s rights.

articles.headline: With Detention of Sarkozy, France Laments Presidency’s Faded Grandeur
articles.snippet: The detention of Nicolas Sarkozy is a new low for an office created by Charles de Gaulle as the acme of political power and the embodiment of French glory.
articles.abstract: The detention of Nicolas Sarkozy is a new low for an office created by Charles de Gaulle as the acme of political power and the embodiment of French glory.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The monarchical majesty of the French presidency suffered an undignified blow early this year when paparazzi photographed the head of state, François Hollande, scurrying away on the back of a scooter from an assignation with a secret lover. This week it took an unprecedented new hit: Mr. Hollande’s predecessor in the Élysée Palace, Nicolas Sarkozy, whose phone had been tapped by investigators, was taken into police custody.

articles.headline: Google Starts Erasing Links for Searches in Europe
articles.snippet: Google began its effort to comply with a European court ruling that said it must help people clean up their online reputations.
articles.abstract: Google began its effort to comply with a European court ruling that said it must help people clean up their online reputations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May, a European court told Google it must assist people in cleaning up their online reputations by ruling that there is a “right to be forgotten.”
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and Noam Cohen

articles.headline: Carol Loomis, Editor for Warren Buffett, Leaves Job After 60 Years
articles.snippet: Ms. Loomis, 85, is retiring from Fortune magazine to a world of bridge playing and — you guessed it — continuing to edit her old friend’s writing.
articles.abstract: Ms. Loomis, 85, is retiring from Fortune magazine to a world of bridge playing and — you guessed it — continuing to edit her old friend’s writing.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January 1954, a bright-eyed 24-year-old from Cole Camp, Mo., walked into Fortune magazine’s offices at Rockefeller Center. Armed with a college journalism degree and work experience writing for a Maytag company magazine, she took an entry-level job assisting Fortune’s male writers.

articles.headline: The Town Where Immigrants Hit a Human Wall
articles.snippet: Busloads of immigrants who roll into Murrieta, Calif., for processing at a Border Patrol center have been met by protesters brandishing American flags and screaming, “Go home!”
articles.abstract: Busloads of immigrants who roll into Murrieta, Calif., for processing at a Border Patrol center have been met by protesters brandishing American flags and screaming, “Go home!”
articles.lead_paragraph: MURRIETA, Calif. — Suddenly, this city in the desert has become the place that turned away the immigrants.

articles.headline: Obama’s Blueprint for Fighting Terrorism Collides With Reality in Iraq
articles.snippet: The seizing of large parts of Iraq by Sunni militants has laid bare the limitations of a terrorism policy that relies on the cooperation of often balky and overmatched partners.
articles.abstract: The seizing of large parts of Iraq by Sunni militants has laid bare the limitations of a terrorism policy that relies on the cooperation of often balky and overmatched partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaking at West Point in May, President Obama laid out a blueprint for fighting terrorism that relies less on American soldiers, like the cadets in his audience that day, and more on training troops in countries where those threats had taken root.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Michael R. Gordon and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: German Man Arrested as Spy Implicates U.S.
articles.snippet: German news media reported that the man, 31, worked for Germany’s intelligence service and was suspected of spying for the United States.
articles.abstract: German news media reported that the man, 31, worked for Germany’s intelligence service and was suspected of spying for the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In the latest turn in the yearlong tensions with Germany over American spying, a German man was arrested this week on suspicion of passing secret documents to a foreign power, believed to be the United States. The American ambassador, John B. Emerson, was summoned to the Foreign Office here and urged to help with what German officials called a swift clarification of the case.
